Ok, I have to say that I really like this game.  It's very similar to the Wing Commander : Privateer model of a golden path where you have an open world, horizontal gameplay and character development with a game story waiting for you to follow it.

There's trading, truck upgrades, modular weapons, towns, factions, and an open world map to boot.  The graphics are 2006-ish but if you're looking for gameplay, you can look past that.

The vehicles themselves are based around chassis that have stats but each chassis also has multiple front and back body components which different turret / upgrade / cargo slots.   Not all weapon slots are 360 degrees which adds a positional element to combat.

The game won't work out of the box for Windows 7.  You have to delete the videos in your Steam\SteamApps\common\Hard Truck Apocalypse\data\video directory.

reviewText:
Now, I can't say this is alike any game that most people know- for it certainly isn't. It's like a mix of Twisted Metal, Fallout, and Mad-Max style combat with a huge amount of cheesey- and probably bad- translations. It's a Russian game with dated graphics and a decently written story. It's a tale of revenge, messenger-like objectives, and mystery. The lore is actually really complex, and there are some side quests you can take more than the random Bartender mission. Yeah, those guys give you random missions that help early game but are wastes of time in later game due to the prices.
Now, I find it funny that every character wears a Ghost-of-the-opera-esque mask, and lore-wise they explain they're basically a more ornate and compacted Gas mask. I think they made them because they didn't want to have to animate faces, haha. Voice acting is absurd in English; so you may want to just play it in the original Russian with subtitles. This game still has its problems.

Pros:
-Excellent Story and Lore
-Wonderful control system; works pretty well and can be re-assigned if need be.
-Interesting Mechanics- Fuel is a thing, tons of truck upgrades, pretty unique storage system.
-Design of the trucks looks amazing; You even get monstrosities that are crosses between monstertrucks and tanks, wield five guns at once, and guzzle gas faster than five hummers from an oil tank that must be the size of a pond.
-A few hillarious glitches: Pedestrians walk into your truck during cutscenes and splat with a noise like a bug, grass floats, that sort of thing.

Cons:
-Dated Graphics; it's an old game, but that can be looked over.
-A few major glitches; One game breaking one stopped me from palying for nearly a year until I found a guide. Careful when you get to the oil shiping mission in the desert.
-Gets boring at times- you'll spend sometimes an hour or more crossing over three regions that you've cleared before, one-shotting the old enemies and getting worthless crap.
-AI can be a bit of an idiot at times; crashs into enemies, drives off of cliffs, gets stuck on debris.

All in all, I would suggest this game. It's enjoyable and very, very unique- plus it gives me a laugh every now and then, even if it wasn't intended. I'm pretty sure they weren't; but it's funny when a bandit yells something nonsensical anyways. If you want a game of strange bandits, amazing truck combat, massive- and sometimes excellent- landscapes, amazing story, and silly translations, BUY THIS GAME. It's worth it.

There are a lot of games on Steam, but once in a while, you browse the catalogue and discover a little gem hiding somewhere in the deep ends of the underated section. Ex Machina is one of those games, but let me start off by saying that this game certainly isn't for everyone, it's genre is considered to be a very acquired taste, but I would say it's worth the buy anyway just for the sake of trying it. I didn't expect it to be anything amazing given it's lack of popularity, but I was wrong, this game is truly brilliant.
If by some coincidence you were attracted to this game because you are a fan of Takara's Road Trip Adventure or Seek & Destroy (otherwise known as the ChoroQ games) like me, then you definitely shouldn't miss out on this, it brings the best of both of those Worlds together!

Ex Machina is about the young protagonist searching for lots of answers & vengeance, depending on the story options you go along with, in a post apocalyptic representation of north America. You start off with one of the weaker vehicles in the game but are given the oportunity to work your way up the ladder by getting coins for doing jobs or selling loot and scrap to people and villages thus giving you the chance to buy new vehicles or upgrade your existing one. Sell the dropped weapons of the enemy, use the money to buy yourself a bigger, better one! The game starts off a little bit slow, but the pace picks up over the course of the game.
Not much else can be said without giving away spoilers, but the story can be very extensive depending on what choices you make during your experience, this is something I really enjoy about Ex Machina, that there isn't just one set plot but rather multiple different routes and storylines that can occur.

The game has it's quirks, in fact, it is a very quirky game, it also has some minor annoyances such as some spelling and grammatical mistakes (this is due to the original version of the game being Russian resulting in a bad translation). The voice acting leaves much to be desired and the dialog is sometimes far from brilliant, but this game really does a lot more things right than it does wrong. The open world, the long story with alternate endings and plots, tons of optional quests, upgrades and weapon variety are something many games in this day and age can learn from. It really is a shame that this game doesn't have a very large community because it really is wonderful, even if it has somewhat dated graphics. There is also no warp function, meaning you have to drive to everywhere you need to go rather than magically appearing there with the click of a button, this can sometimes be tedious but is also another great addition to this open world game.

If you've been watching this, I highly recommend giving it a go, I can't promise you will enjoy it because as I said above, it definitely isn't for everybody, but it is certainly something unique. Some of the reviews on here and the expert" reviews on other sites seem to be by people who tried the game for all of 20 minutes and decided to stop playing for some reason or other as they never go into any detail as to why they gave negative reviews

reviewText:
Well, after long years of being a huge fan of this game, I finally finished it (I had an original Russian actual version released by Buka company).

My feelings are mixed. I'd like to point out some pros and cons for the game, and you guys will judge for yourself.

I solemnly swear to keep it spoiler-free for those who still hasn't finished it.

Pros:
* A pseudo open world to explore. Due to some scripted restrictions you cannot simly go to, say, Vaterland from Krai. But it doens't mean that actual exploration is not fun and to some extent rewarding.
* A variety of trucks to choose from with a great deal of customization. I love all of them, except for maybe Belaz since I didin't touch it at all.
* A wide variety of weapons to satisfy anyone's taste, from machine guns to plasma cannons.
* Lovely soundtrack and visuals. A bit outdated, but the game is almost a decade old! Explosions and energy particles tho.
* The narrative in terms of lore. Just read the in-game books.

Cons:
* Extremely poor narrative. Both from the point of telling a story and the story itself. I dunno, maybe it's just those Masks that make every character to look the same way? Or voice acting? Or the final which is a HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT?
* A dumb AI. More in a matter of path-finding than fighting. Extremely stupid! Sometimes a bunch of trucks cannot make it through a hill because instead of driving around they try to come over it.
* Not really much stuff to do aside from some interesting side quests now and then.
*  The final boss battle. A huge disappointment also. No spoilers!
* Dialogue is just a stub. I understand that in such a mission there need to be less talk and more action but damn! I felt sorry for coming to Ben's place and leaving the same instance without even saying good bye. No love for the old guy.
* Restrictions on where to go and what to do. Try to cross that river in Vaterland. Just go and do it.
* Some things are just unnecessary. For example, some inter-regional shortcuts. I never used them and have a feeling that never will. Sad but true.

CONLUSION: This game has it's flaws, and narrative leaves a nasty touch on my tongue. But I still love this game. For the sense of freedom that it managed to give to me despite all those restrictions to go where I want. For the atmosphere of post-apocalyptic road to nowhere. You just go where the wind blows. I just wish I could dive into this world a bit more, leaving all that main storyline somewhere on the side. Actually, a sandbox open-world RPG in HTA setting would be much appreciated and would become a must-have in my collection. Maybe with some neat multiplayer like it was, say, in Freelancer? I don't know, and probably will never know.

Anyway, that's my review. Still love this game and recommend it to everyone interested. Give this game a try.

Imagine Vigilante 8: Second Offense crossed with S. T. A. L. K. E. R.

Set in a postapocalyptic world, you, a young farmer with a truck, have to trade, fend off bandits and discover what happened to your father.

You can (and have to) outfit your vehicle, ranging from simple buggies to heavy duty trucks to armored personnel carriers, with all manner of weaponry including machine guns, shotguns, missile launchers, energy weapons, mine layers, tank cannons and mortars. There are also gadgets that improve your car such as extended fuel tanks, weapon cooling systems and turbo boosters among other things.

Towns serve as trading posts, repair stations and quest hubs. Most quests revolve around delivering goods to other towns, escort missions (which are few and far between) and kill as many bandits as possible in a set time limit (usually 3 minutes).

Graphics are ok, keep in mind that this is an older game.

Music is fitting to the postapocalyptic setting, consisting mostly of rock tunes, my favorite theme being the one which plays in Hel. Although i wish there were more tracks.

Guns sound good, i really like the meaty sound of the cannons.

All in all it's a nice game, i got around 16 hours of gameplay on my 1st run (there is a certain amount of back tracking).

Be sure to check out the forum for a step by step guide to prevent the game from crashing and how to run it in 1920x1080 resolution.

A decent game with some flaws.
This is one-of-a-kind game, you drive a truck, fight other trucks, collect and trade gear, go on missions, talk with people in cities, buy new gear and trucks in said cities, visit several lands, all the while trying to discover who killed your father.
It sports one of the best soundtracks ever, which adds to the post-apocalyptic atmosphere.
Combat is against other trucks, generally you'll have three adversaries which spawn and try to chase you.
Pathfinding is ridiculous. Merchants carry goods from city to city, but mostly try to climb up trees or manouver in circles. Baddies are a little bit more intelligent, they'll follow you but they never reach full speed, so it's very easy to just outrun them. There are also some scripted ambushes and boss battles.
The plot is nothing new, but it gives a thread to follow, and opens new areas to explore.
Trading goods generates good money - and you'll need it to buy more powerful trucks - but the best way to strike it rich is through combat and gathering of the remains of your enemies.

The game lacks polish, the translation is approximative and it has its lot of annoying bugs, but it can be quite rewarding when you buy a new truck, new gun or discover a new area to explore. Even the plot becomes interesting after a while.

Give it a try, it's worth your time.

reviewText:
Overall it's actually a pretty good game. I was honestly surprised. It has some problems but it's also got a lot that makes it very interesting as a game. An easy way to describe the game is a mix of the X series, Fallout series and trucks. It's a post-apocalyptic Privateer game where you control any sort of truck complete with weapons of all sorts.

Pros:
-Well designed gameplay. Good controls that do give you some of the heft of driving a truck.
-Plenty of weapons, that are even more realistic with varying penetration and degradibility.
-Large open world to explore.
-RPG elements, mostly in the form of quests.
-Trading system that where you can use coins gathered from quests, bartering or loot to get new weapons and supplies.
-Accurate damage modeling. I love when games do this because it makes it feel like you actually took damage. Your cab and your hold both take independent damage, and things such as damage tires and even bullet holes in where you were shot show up. However, damaged tires don't seem to affect the performance of the truck which I thought was weird.

Cons:
-Bad voice acting, if not downright wooden. You can tell that it's been translated literally from another language.
-Poor AI, at least on easier difficulties. I know that AI isn't supposed to be so grueling on easier settings, but I can honestly run into one with a consistent spray of machine gun fire and destroy it in a few seconds.
-Graphics are a little bland. Although most post-apocalyptic games are like this due to the lack of lush life so I don't have a major problem with it.

Overall, it's a fun game and I've barely gone down the rabbit hole in two hours. I see a lot of content in this one, and with all the decently-priced cards to sell you'd be hard pressed not to get it while it's on sale.

8/10

reviewText:
An old rusty truck, whole lotta oil, a gun, and your journal. Shrouded in mistery your life is filled with numerous puzzle pieces that lead to a much bigger picture. Who are you? Who are these people? Where am I? What is this all about? Seek and you shall find, even learn more than the storyline is telling. Old worn out roads, telephone lines, monuments, secret places, biomes, the world of HTA just doesn't seem to have an end, and the story will put you in the right post-apocayptic mood for many hours.

Pros:

-Many hours of gameplay.
-Well designed open world (for an old game that is)
-Role play fun.
-Many quests, items, characters to reveal.
-Unique gameplay experience, very rare for this kind of game.
-A chilling storyline.

Cons:

-No autosave, if you don't save manually every now and then you will be left stranded. The manual saving works very well though.
-Few annoying bugs, they can be bypassed though.
-Lack of storyline detail in some quests, ie, could use more cutscenes and speech.
-Can get exhausting in travel at times.
-No multiplayer. If only this game had full-blown MP support!

Conclusion:

HTA is my second indie open world favorite for a very good reason. I've just replayed it for 7th-8th time after many years of not playing this game, and I can assure you the experience is memorable to say the least. My first indie open world favorite is A.I.M 1 and 2, which were developed and published by the same authors, and inhibit similar open world and post-apocalypse setting and storyline like HTA, albeit with a lot more detail and story telling. I strongly recommend both games and their sequels HTA: Clan Wars and A.I.M 2. If you treasure unique gaming experience look no further.

I have mixed emotions about this one. Just going to quickly say if you are about the graphics I suggest looking over this one. If however you do like gameplay and a RPG type thing with a truck, then heck this game is for you.

This camera angle helps to shoot an opponent while remaining stable. Although you cant always see your truck, this sort of gives a bit of freedoms driving around (given you can see your truck which way your shooting).

It's a interesting game and would recommend buying it on sale if your looking for something different. I also wasn't a big fan of the voice acting.

If you're looking for a ground breaking game I suggest you keep going.

6.9/10

Hard Truck Apocalypse (released 2005/2006) is a game I was looking forward to playing. I expected a mash of Interstate 76 but with an open world feeling like Privateer. It delivered on these core concepts but that was all.

- Moddable.

Cons:

- Too much money after the half way mark. Didn't even bother to loot.

- Long pauses between dialogue (and even then the dialogue was a chore to listen to).

reviewText:
The good:
Not much. Just to be clear I am going to slam this game long and hard below because I believe in being brutally honest, but there is actually some enjoyment to be had here. It may have its problems and be quite generic even for a game made in 2005, but the combat is not poorly done and overall the game is not poorly done. If you do not get bored easily and can appreciate that this game was released during the prehistoric age of gaming (2007 or before) and don't go into it with high expectations, you will find that it runs perfectly smooth with no technical issues (for me anyway) and is done competently enough that, as I said, a fair level of enjoyment can be gleaned from your time spent.

The bad:
Terribly generic and old. Anything 2007 and older (this is 05) is the prehistoric age of gaming and the farther we get away from those times of depressingly basic PC game programming equivalent to cavemen drawing on walls, the better. I became a PC gamer back in 1997 but I can admit that until more recent years gaming was just never very satisfying because technology has only finally become what gamers have been waiting for. Driving within five feet of a rock causes a collision even if you can visibly see you aren’t touching it. Collision detection/being stuck is a real problem: there is a unstuck key (O) but it only works selectively. It worked once earlier in the game for me, but recently it would not. I was fighting a truck and I wasn't watching where I was driving because it is tough to do while also having to aim at a enemy, and I rammed into a tree, broke it and it fell over, and it left behind an invisible stump underneath my truck that I was teetering on and could not get off of so I had to reload my game which thankfully I had just quicksaved a minute earlier. That's another thing about this game: no autosave whatsoever. F2 is quicksave and F3 is quickload, so be ready to press F2 constantly. Textures are poorly done: the graphics generally look like absolute garbage and I have seen on several occasions patches of grass floating a few feet above the ground. All textures also pop in and out: if it is going offscreen it will disappear until you move the camera in that direction and it will pop back in. This one is hilarious: your minimap has a N at the top meaning of course “North” but it also has a S at the bottom meaning of course “South”. The first couple hours playing this game I assumed it was a dollar sign because I do not recall ever seeing any game with more than just a N on the minimap, which if you have a N on the radar to show you which way is north, why the fk would you need an S at the bottom? Just astonishing. Probably the most intolerable part of the game is that it has the worst music in the history of gaming. But without the music on you are driving through miles of barren, lifeless, boring wasteland with nothing to do, no other cars to kill usually, so without the music all you are going to hear while driving is the hum of the engine, which is a poor sound effect at that. I suppose I could turn off the game's ear-bleedingly bad music and play my own music on windows media player but that still won't change the fact that you are going to be driving miles upon miles through nothing while doing nothing. You will have a TON of that in this game: driving through a wasteland with nothing to do but try not to fall asleep at the wheel. Sometimes you get to kill other cars, sometimes... You can't touch anything while driving or you will rack your repair bill up the @ss and repairs are not cheap: I broke through a wooden fence and it dropped my durability from 850 to 810 lol are you kidding me. It gets worse too: I was driving past a piece of fence and was clearly about 5ft away from it and it sort of snagged my truck and made it whip around and slam into a second row of fence beyond it, reducing my durability on my truck big time. Some of the worst programmed AI I've ever seen: enemies get stuck on objects sometimes and you just blast the ♥♥♥♥ out of them. Sometimes friendly AI vehicles will repeatedly try to slam through an unsmashable gate to get into the quest area where you are waiting to advance the game, whereas if they would just back up and go to the left or right a little they can get in. But no! ♥♥♥♥ that! Lets keep backing up and try to repeatedly ram through this solidly programmed gate! I suppose that can be added to the good" section I have above since it really is pretty funny.

Overall

reviewText:
Verdict: Avoid at all costs.

WARNING: Does NOT work as advertised on Win 8.1 or Win 7 64-bit.

Do not let my Steam-recorded 'playtime' fool you: all time I've spent on this was purely trying to get it to just start successfully, which it did not, not even once, on neither of the tested rigs.

Not after following the community-offered fixes of deleting the video files (seriously, *video* files make the game crash? That should be a first hint right there), manually editing the config files from the default just to get a reasonable screen resolution, crafting a special shortcut to prevent it from running on more than one CPU core (how many PCs these days have a single-core CPU anymore?), and disallowing Steam updates to avoid a standard mechanism from undoing all the required fixes.

Not even after following unreadable non-translated Russian quintuple-redirected patch download links on pure faith. I almost stopped clicking through after the fifth redirect level, way more than my sense of computing security wanted to allow me to, and now it is justifiably nagging at me from the back of my mind for running the risk with zero reward, since even the acclaimed community-created patch did not make things work (no offence to my Russian co-gamers, but clicking through links one cannot read that keep redirecting away to yet more sites one cannot read, is just not safe Internet practice, and I am sure many non-Russians are stopped from downloading the patch because of that. Even a purely Google-translated blurb with a direct download link would go far at making it at least 'feel' safer, warranted or not).

The devs themselves, despite obviously being very much not dead as shown by their posts, and despite feeling quite ok about still asking money for their broken product, are unwilling to either fix their own product or to validate the community-created patch by making it an official part of the Steam download.

This game should plainly NOT be advertised as working on Win7/8, and should definitely not be sold as such. That creative and persistent community members managed to (sometimes? mostly?) make it work through more effort than is warranted for a paying customer, does not mean you are allowed to advertise something for what it is not.

Which in the end is a damn shame, because the videos make it look like good fun. I went into this eyes open since I always read forums before-hand, and it looked fun enough to warrant some effort to get a clearly abandoned game to work. That 'some effort' unfortunately turned out to be more time than I have spent on fully playing through other very enjoyable games, to get zero results. I had one last workaround in mind (creating a dedicated WinXP VM to run the game in) but frankly I have not found any further energy to try anymore. Money totally wasted, since the devs show no signs or initiative of fixing this, not even by admitting defeat and accepting community help.

Avoid at all costs unless you have an old pre-win7 system lying around; and considering the types and severity of the crashing bugs, maybe not even then, but I cannot vouch for it either way. Others obviously are having more success, but it's far from guaranteed to work for you and more effort than many will want to spend.
